text: hi everyone Anthony Fantana here

album nobody's smiling

name

I'm dead he's still gonna be around in

opinion one of hip-hop's true hippies in
a good way if you're ever in the mood
for some classic thought-provoking
Midwest hip hop do give albums like
resurrection and one day it'll all make
sense a listen this guy's career started
in the 90s during this decade he dropped
some really good features with De La
Soul as well as the roots as he
progressed into the 2000s he would work
with black star as well as Kanye West
who has produced for his albums on
numerous occasions and into the 2000s
his artistic momentum seemed to carry on
as well with really great albums like
water for chocolate and B which was his
inaugural album for Kanye West's GOOD
Music label a label that he has been on
ever since with the exception of his
last full-length LP the dreamer the
believer which in my opinion was one of
Commons least memorable albums in years
even though it sort of did mark a new
era of his career plus it was not really
marketed or promoted that well I think
this album was dropped like five days
before Christmas which is maybe one of
the worst times you can put out a
commercial record and the singles off of
this LP weren't even really that sticky
or controversial or hot more people were
talking about common
subliminal beef with Drake at the time
then they were the music on this record
with this new record of his however I am
sensing a little bit more of a commotion
around this new stuff though I do still
think common might be in the midst of an
artistic dry spell that I think he's
been in ever since the album universal
mind control with tracks like make my
day and sex for sugar I think this album
has some of his worst songs ever on it a
lot of Commons fans might not be head
over heels for an album like finding
forever but I find this record to be way
more interesting and eclectic than the
more commercial stuff he's been putting
out lately yeah I do like albums like
water for chocolate as well as B but I
also admire some of Commons more
left-field releases like Electric Circus
where you get hints of not only hip hop
but rock and soul and pop music plus
there are a ton of interesting features
on this record common being one of the
first big-name rappers to sort of bridge
that hip-hop indie gap allowing somebody
like laticious Adair onto his record now
like I said 2011 and the dreamer the
believer sort of marked a new era for
Commons career with this last release of
his I feel like we're kind of getting
the story and the mindset of an aging
old schooler who's kind of embracing his
home and celebrating his untouchable
spot in hip hop history though there are
moments on this record where I do feel
like Kamen might be coming off in a way
where it just feels like he's trying a
little too hard to be aggressive or
badass sort of like on the song sweet
which i think is absolutely crazy
truthfully I'm enjoying Commons flow and
his lyrical content a lot more on this
latest LP of his nobody's smiling but I
can't say I'm really enjoying it more
than the dreamer the believer because it
brings a host of entirely different
issues to the table now for sure there
are some serious highlights on the cell
peace songs that I think are great but
they just happen to occur at the very
beginning and the very end of the album
there's the track the neighborhood where
Kamen delivers a bunch of grimy sobering
Street centric lines that seem really
dismal there's a lot of violence
referenced in the way
a lot of lost hope people just getting
caught in the violence of this concrete

I would expect from an album titled
nobody's smiling given that common is
from Chicago and has given an album

the instrumental is fantastic on this
thing I love the strings weaved into
this beat and there is a fantastic
feature from little herb on this track
to check out his faisal lanin mixtape
that dropped earlier this year that I've
given a review and did like these same
lyrical themes Landover a much more
ominous and and quiet subtle beat on the
song no fear right after and then we
have the song kingdom with vince staples
another good feature on this record and
it's a conceptual track it's a theme
track about somebody who is young
growing up in a violent city and trying
to find solace in God in religion but
having a difficult time relating paying
attention finding value in this because
it's so hard to survive in this violent
urban setting in my opinion these are
great tracks so good that there's
there's really no reason to lose faith
in common as he is aging in his rap
career he could still write really
coherent interesting captivating songs
but he doesn't keep this consistency up
throughout the middle of the record
there's the song diamonds which could
have been a quality track but Big Shot
is featured on this song and delivers
one of the worst features I've heard
this year he basically moseys on in into
the song of a hip hop legend and moans
and ad-libs ridiculously in between
Commons verses common should not have
allowed this Big Sean should not have
done it everyone should have known
better
then there's the song black magic which
I enjoy lyrically but it has one of the
most obnoxious instrumentals on the
entire LP black magic black magic black
magic and the song speak my piece maybe
one of my least favorite tracks
lyrically it's just sort of a bunch of
forgettable braggadocio from common not
that I don't want him to brag when he
does see success but it's not like it's
that much of a thrill to hear him rap
about his spot in the hip-hop industry
right now especially when you have
people like jay-z who
are a little more riveting with it Plus

of carries the song out until the next
song decides to play this same week
structuring hurts
the title track on this album as well I

bringing thus far it seems like common
gets things going and either doesn't

as far as features aside from Vince

that that song displays it's got a great

different seven deadly sins in his
lyrics and it's a common solo track you
don't have anybody

it's still a better track than say
diamonds or real this is an alright

I do have just really strong feelings
for some of these bonus tracks
I think Commons started well with this
record I think he ended well with this
record especially with her wine that
which is a beautiful song that sort of
reflects upon his time in the hip hop
industry creating music with different
people one verse specifically centering
around J Dilla the time when he was
making music with him when he received
beats from him sort of seeing him pass
away before his eyes it's really moving
part of this record even if this song
was not about J Dilla this would be an
amazing track simply because Kamen gives
such a personal recollection of the life
of a very close friend who is not around
anymore if this kind of consistency if
this kind of heart-wrenching
storytelling continued throughout this
record I could see it being a total
winner and a standout in his discography
but instead we get filler we get moments
like Big Sean on diamonds that couldn't
be worse for the album's flow I'm
